column1: Fremantle () is a port city in Western Australia
column2: located at the mouth of the Swan River in the metropolitan area of Perth
column3: the state capital. Fremantle Harbour serves as the port of Perth. In 2016
column4: Fremantle had a population of approximately 29
column5: 000. The Western Australian vernacular diminutive for Fremantle is Freo.Prior to British settlement
column6: the indigenous Noongar people inhabited the area for millennia
column7: and knew it by the  name of Walyalup ("place of the woylie"). Visited by Dutch explorers in the 1600s
column8: Fremantle was the first area settled by the Swan River colonists in 1829
column9: and is named after Captain Charles Fremantle
column10: an English naval officer who claimed the west coast of New Holland as British territory. The settlement struggled in its first decades
column12: with the advent of penal transportation to the colony
column13: Fremantle became Australia's primary destination for convicts. The convict-built Fremantle Prison operated long after transportation ended in 1868
column14: and is now a World Heritage Site.

column1: Fremantle was charted as a municipality in 1883
column2: and the following decade its harbour was deepened for commercial shipping
column3: transforming the port into a bustling trade centre and gateway at the height of the Western Australian gold rushes. Declared a city in 1929
column4: Fremantle played a key role in World War II as the largest submarine base in the Southern Hemisphere. Post-war immigration from Europe
column5: particularly Italy
column6: helped shape Fremantle's character
column7: and it rapidly gentrified after hosting the 1987 America's Cup. Today
column8: Fremantle is recognised for its well-preserved Victorian and Edwardian streetscapes and convict-era heritage
column9: and is known as a bohemian enclave with a thriving arts and culinary scene. It is also the traditional home of the Fremantle Football Club
column10: one of two Australian Football League teams based in Western Australia.

column1: The original inhabitants of the land on which the city of Fremantle is built are the Whadjuk Noongar people
column2: who called the area Walyalup ("place of the woylie"). To the local Noongar people
column3: Fremantle is a place of ceremonies
column4: significant cultural practices and trading. For millennia the Noongar people met there in spring and autumn to feast on fish and game.Anglesea Point and the limestone hill area at Arthur Head (where the Round House prison stands) to Point Marquis was called Manjaree
column5: an important meeting place where bush paths converged and a major trading place for Whadjuk and neighbouring Noongars. Today
column6: Whadjuk and other Noongars continue to gather and meet in Walyalup and at Manjaree.

column1: The first Europeans to visit the site of modern-day Fremantle were Dutch explorers captained by Willem de Vlamingh
column2: in 1697. They mapped the area and went up the Swan River
column3: and Vlamingh reported that it would be an ideal place for a settlement
column4: although no attempts were made at the time.

column1: The area was considered as a site for possible British settlement in 1827
column2: when Captain James Stirling
column3: in HMS Success
column4: explored the coastal areas near the Swan River. His favourable report was welcomed by the British Government
column5: who had for some time been suspicious of French colonial intentions towards the western portion of Australia. As a result of Stirling's report
column6: Captain Charles Fremantle of HMS Challenger
column7: a 603-ton
column9: was instructed to sail to the west coast of Australia to establish a settlement there.On 2 May 1829
column10: Fremantle hoisted the Union Flag in a bay near what is now known as Arthur Head
column11: and in accordance with his instructions
column12: took formal possession "of the whole of the West Coast of New Holland" in the name of Britain's King George IV.Western Australia Day (formerly Foundation Day) is observed on the first Monday in June
column13: although it was actually on 2 June 1829 that Captain James Stirling on the Parmelia arrived with Surveyor-General Roe and the first contingent of immigrants to set up the Swan River Colony. The settlement of Perth began on 12 August 1829.

column1: Captain Fremantle left the colony on 25 August after providing much assistance to Stirling in setting up the colony. It was then that Stirling decided to name the port settlement "Fremantle".In early September 1829 the merchant vessel Anglesea grounded at Gage Roads
column2: at the mouth of the Swan River. She did not break up
column3: as had been expected
column4: but instead survived to become Western Australia's first prison hulk. Lotus
column5: which arrived on 10 October 1829
column6: became the second vessel to land immigrants at Fremantle.On 1 June 1850
column7: the first convicts arrived at Fremantle aboard the Scindian. The thirty-seventh and last convict ship to dock at Fremantle was the Hougoumont on 10 January 1868
column8: signalling the end of penal transportation to Australia. Among the 280 convicts on board were 62 Fenian military and political prisoners—members of the Irish Republican Brotherhood—six of whom managed to escape the Convict Establishment in the Catalpa rescue of 1876. During this period
column9: notorious South Sea pirate Bully Hayes lived in Fremantle with his fiancée Miss Scott
column10: daughter of the Fremantle Harbour Master.

column2: Irish-born engineer C. Y. O'Connor deepened Fremantle Harbour and removed the limestone bar and sand shoals across the entrance to the Swan River
column3: thus rendering Fremantle a serviceable port for commercial shipping. This occurred at the height of the late 19th-century Western Australian gold rush
column4: transforming Fremantle into a capital of trade and gateway for thousands of gold miners to the inland boom towns of Coolgardie
column5: Kalgoorlie and Southern Cross. Camels and their Afghan drivers were familiar sights
column6: and by-laws regulating the driving of camels through the streets of Fremantle were enacted. The wealth generated during this period resulted in the construction of several prestigious hotels throughout Fremantle (see heritage buildings). Fremantle still serves as the chief general seaport for Western Australia
column7: though far greater tonnages are exported from the iron-ore ports of the Pilbara.

column2: Fremantle was the home of the largest base for Allied submarines in the Southern Hemisphere
column3: and the second largest in the Pacific War after Pearl Harbor. In the lead-up to and during the war
column4: the port's existing batteries were upgraded and new ones were constructed
column5: forming a coastal defence system referred to as Fremantle Fortress. There were up to 125 US
column6: 31 British and 11 Free Dutch submarines operating out of Fremantle
column7: until the Americans moved forward to the Philippines. One of the first US submarines to arrive in Fremantle
column9: was bombed by an Australian Lockheed Hudson
column10: which mistook it for a Japanese vessel. The movements and presence of USS Sturgeon (SS-187) is a good example of such activity.

column1: Fremantle was considered a "veritable Shangri-la" among submariners during the war
column2: however tensions between transient American and non-American soldiers often led to alcohol-fuelled violence. On 11 April 1944
column3: a brawl between American and New Zealand servicemen at the National Hotel resulted in many injuries and the death from stab wounds of two Māori soldiers.

column1: The City of Fremantle introduced several urban renewal projects in 2012
column2: encouraging mixed-use development by increasing the maximum building height on key sites in the CBD
column3: including Kings Square and the inner East End. In January 2013
column4: the City of Fremantle became the first council in Australia to outlaw the use of non-degradable plastic bags within their local area.

column1: Fremantle lies on a series of limestone hills known by the Nyungar people as Booyeembara; the sandplain to the east is Gardoo. The original vegetation of the area was mainly Xanthorrhoea and eucalyptus trees
column2: which were traditionally fired annually by the Aboriginal people.

column1: The suburb of Fremantle is bounded by the Swan River to the north and north-west
column2: the Indian Ocean to the west
column3: South Street to the south
column4: and the suburbs of East Fremantle and White Gum Valley to the east. The central part of the suburb extends eastwards to include Royal Fremantle Golf Club and a suburban area south of Marmion Street and west of Carrington Street. The City of Fremantle local government area also includes the suburbs of Beaconsfield
column5: Hilton
column6: North Fremantle
column7: O'Connor
column10: and White Gum Valley. East Fremantle has its own town council and is not governed by the City of Fremantle.

column1: Fremantle is the end of the Fremantle railway line which runs from Perth to Fremantle
column2: run by the Western Australia's Public Transport Authority. Major highways including Stirling Highway
column3: Canning Highway and Leach Highway have Fremantle as their start point and/or terminus.

column1: Fremantle has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen: Csa). The regular sea breeze is known as the Fremantle Doctor
column2: as it provides cooling relief from the summer heat when it arrives between noon and 3pm. Fremantle is generally a few degrees cooler than Perth in summer.

column1: The Fremantle state seat was continuously held by the Australian Labor Party from 1924 until 2009
column2: when it was lost at a by-election to Greens candidate Adele Carles. The seat was returned to Labor (Simone McGurk) in the 2013 state election. The federal electorate has returned Labor members continuously since 1934
column3: including former Prime Minister John Curtin
column4: and is represented by Josh Wilson.

column1: The local government of the City of Fremantle consists of a mayor and council. Brad Pettitt has been the mayor since the 2009 local government elections.
Fremantle has been represented by some significant Australian political figures. John Curtin served as Prime Minister during the Second World War
column2: and is often described as one of the nation's greatest political leaders. The state's largest university and a major secondary school in Fremantle are named after him
column3: and his statue stands in Kings Square near the Fremantle Town Hall. A long-serving mayor of the town
column4: Sir Frank Gibson (1919–1923 and 1926–1952)
column5: was also a Liberal parliamentarian from 1942 to 1956. Gibson
column6: a pharmacist with a shop in High Street
column7: was admired by all sides of politics for his civic leadership and tireless work for the city
column8: especially during the Second World War
column9: when he is said to have visited every ship that called at the port. He was a leading figure in many civic organisations and his stepson
column11: was medical officer with the 2nd/2nd Independent Company during the Timor campaign in the Second World War. Carmen Lawrence
column12: the first female premier of an Australian state
column13: later represented Fremantle in the federal House of Representatives.

column1: Fremantle has seen many industrial conflicts
column2: the most famous of which occurred in 1919 when rioting broke out during the Battle of the Barricades
column3: resulting in one death and many injuries.On 10 November 2006
column4: Australian state and territory attorneys general met in Fremantle to sign the Fremantle Declaration
column5: a restatement and affirmation of legal and human rights principles in Australia. In 2011
column6: Prime Minister Julia Gillard launched the Commonwealth Youth Forum in Fremantle as part of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2011
column7: held in Perth 28–30 October.

column1: Fremantle is renowned for its well-preserved architectural heritage
column2: including convict-built structures and hundreds of gold rush-era buildings
column3: presenting a variety and unity of historic buildings and streetscapes. These were often built in limestone with ornate façades in a succession of architectural styles. Rapid development following the harbour works gave rise to an Edwardian precinct as merchant and shipping companies built in the west end and on reclaimed land.The Round House
column4: the oldest remaining intact building in Western Australia
column5: was built as a gaol between 1830 and 1831. The Round House had eight cells and a gaoler's residence
column6: which all opened up into a central courtyard. In the 1800s
column7: bay whaling was carried out from Bathers Beach below the Round House. As part of the whaling operations
column8: a tunnel was constructed under the Round House to provide whalers with access to the town from the jetty and beach. The Round House is located in what is now known as Fremantle's West End: a collection of streets characterised by late Victorian and Edwardian architecture. A process of gentrification in the early 1990s was accelerated by the establishment of the University of Notre Dame Australia that occupies
column10: many of the buildings in the West End.

column1: When the first 75 convicts arrived from Britain in 1850 to support the colony's dwindling population
column2: it became apparent that the Round House was inadequate to house them. The convicts built a new gaol
column3: Fremantle Prison
column4: which was completed in the 1850s and continued to be used as Fremantle's prison until 1991. Fremantle Prison was once one of the most notorious prisons in the British Empire. It housed British convicts
column5: local prisoners
column6: military prisoners
column7: enemy aliens and prisoners of war. On 1 August 2010
column8: a meeting of the UNESCO World Heritage Committee in Brazil placed Fremantle Prison and 10 other "Australian Convict Sites" on the World Heritage List - making it the first built environment in Western Australia to be bestowed this honour. It continues to be accessible to the public for guided tours and as a venue for artistic and cultural activities.Other convict-built buildings in Fremantle include the 1850s Fremantle School building and Commissariat Buildings
column10: constructed in the 1860s from locally quarried limestone. It is a former lunatic asylum building on Ord Street
column11: and is one of Fremantle's most significant landmarks.  Today the imposing Victorian Gothic building and its historic courtyards are used for art exhibitions and music concerts.

column2: forming a precinct providing handicrafts
column3: speciality foods
column4: dining halls and fish and vegetable markets. The area also hosts buskers and other street performers. The then premier
column5: Sir John Forrest
column6: laid the foundation stone for the markets on Saturday 6 November 1897. Over 150 stalls are housed in the Victorian-era building
column7: which was listed by the National Trust of Australia and the state's Heritage Council in 1980. The Fremantle Markets are adjacent to several other historic buildings
column8: including the Sail & Anchor Hotel (which contains a microbrewery)
column11: the Fremantle Technical School and Scots Presbyterian Church.

column1: Some key historical buildings have been lost to development
column2: while others are only extant thanks to community activism that went against the wishes of developers. For example
column3: the art deco Oriana Cinema on the corner of Queen and High streets was demolished in 1972
column4: after only 34 years of operation. This was done to make way for the widening of High Street
column5: but that project was stopped thanks to the campaigning of the Fremantle Society and other community members
column6: and the buildings along the southern side of High Street were retained. The Fremantle Markets nearly suffered a similar fate in the late 1970s due to another road-widening proposal.The National Hotel
column7: one of the city's historic buildings
column8: was almost destroyed by fire on the night of Sunday
column9: 11 March 2007. Though the interior was gutted
column10: the façade was saved and the building has since been fully restored with an additional rooftop bar.

column1: In the 2016 Australian census conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics
column2: Fremantle had a population of 28
column3: 893 people. 61% of the population was born in Australia
column4: compared with the national average of 67%. Indigenous Australians make up 1.6% of the population
column5: and the largest overseas-born groups come from England (8.8%)
column6: Italy (3.1%)
column7: New Zealand (2.4%)
column9: the most common language spoken at home is Italian (4.5%)
column13: Fremantle had an unemployment rate of 7.4%. The city has an above-average proportion of rented dwellings (33.5%
column14: vs 30.9% nationally). 42% of the population had no religion

column1: University of Notre Dame Australia – Located in the historic West End of Fremantle
column2: the university's presence has contributed to Fremantle often being referred to as a "university town" typical of the older university towns of Europe and the only one of its type in Australia. The restored historic buildings of the campus lend a distinctive character to Notre Dame and with a growing student community
column3: Notre Dame contributes actively to the city.South Metropolitan TAFE – South Metropolitan TAFE has multiple campuses in Fremantle
column4: including its main campus in Beaconsfield
column5: the WA Maritime Training Centre at Victoria Quay
column6: and the E-Tech campus located within the city centre. South Metropolitan TAFE offers a broad range of courses from Certificate I to Advanced Diploma level across multiple campuses and across a diverse range of disciplines.

column1: Curtin University Sustainability Policy Institute (CUSP) - CUSP was established in January 2008 and is headed by sustainability expert
column2: Professor Peter Newman. CUSP has a strong affinity with Fremantle
column3: which in itself is widely regarded as being at the forefront of sustainable practices. The institute welcomes PhD and Masters by Research students
column4: and is offering a coursework Masters in Sustainability.The city centre is also home to a major teaching hospital
column5: Fremantle Hospital.

column1: John Curtin College of the Arts

column2: with over 2
column3: 000 registered businesses operating across a wide range of sectors. Many of the city's enterprises are small businesses
column4: with 75% employing fewer than five people.

column1: Fremantle's biggest employment sector is health care and social assistance – 17.5% of the city's workers are employed in this area
column2: reflecting the important influence of Fremantle Hospital. The transport
column3: postal and warehousing sector employs 12.6% of workers
column4: followed by retail
column5: employing 10.2%. The Local Gross Product of Fremantle was $3
column6: 677 million in 2011.

column1: Fremantle is served by a Community Newspaper Group paper
column2: The Fremantle - Cockburn Gazette
column3: and by an independent local newspaper
column4: the Fremantle Herald.

column1: Fremantle also has two radio stations Radio Fremantle on 107.9FM and 91.3 SportFM.
Online reporting and reviews of events and places within Fremantle are comprehensively covered by a group of local designers on their popular blog
column2: known as 'Love Freo'
column3: and by a local photographer with his daily updated blog Freo's View.

column1: Fremantle offers a wide variety of dining experiences
column2: with a strong emphasis on Italian and Asian cuisine as well as seafood. Various cafés and coffee shops are situated around Fremantle
column3: particularly on the 'Cappuccino Strip'
column4: a section of South Terrace known for its alfresco dining culture. The Fishing Boat Harbour has become a tourist precinct
column5: with a mixture of microbreweries
column6: restaurants and some of Australia's largest fish and chip shops. A number of old buildings on the harbour have been renovated
column7: including Little Creatures Brewery
column8: which occupies a former boat shed and crocodile farm
column9: and contains a café and art gallery. The harbour's annual Fremantle Sardine Festival on Esplanade Park attracts thousands of seafood lovers every year. Other annual events held at the harbour include Araluen's Fremantle Chilli Festival
column11: and the traditional Italian Blessing of the Fleet ceremony.Fremantle—along with the inner suburbs Northbridge
column12: Leederville and Subiaco—is one of Perth's major nightlife hubs. It attracts people from all over the metropolitan region for its pubs

column1: There are several major annual festivals in Fremantle. First held in 1906
column2: the Fremantle Festival is Australia's longest running community festival. International street performers converge for the Fremantle Street Arts Festival
column3: held over the Easter holiday period. The Fremantle Heritage Festival celebrates local history with a variety of events
column4: tours
column5: concerts and workshops.Fremantle is also home to several galleries and museums. The Western Australian Museum has two branches in Fremantle: the Shipwreck Galleries
column6: housed in convict-constructed commissariat buildings and known for its artefacts from the Batavia and other 17th-century Dutch ships; and the Maritime Museum on Victoria Quay
column7: which contains exhibits related to maritime trade and the Indian Ocean. The Army Museum of Western Australia is housed in an historic Fremantle artillery barracks.

column1: The city has a large arts community
column2: with a number of small art galleries and musical venues and a community theatre company
column3: Harbour Theatre Inc.
column4: which has been performing in the city since 1963. There is also the J Shed situated on Bathers' Beach. J Shed houses four artists studios. Old Customs House
column5: a heritage building just across from the working Fremantle Ports
column6: is home to a not-for-profit artists agency
column7: Artsource
column9: and houses several other arts organisations.

column2: Fremantle has given rise to many notable musicians
column3: including AC/DC frontman Bon Scott
column4: who grew up in the city and whose gravesite at Fremantle Cemetery has become a cultural landmark. A statue of Scott was erected in 2009 at the Fishing Boat Harbour. Dom Mariani also grew up in Fremantle
column5: as did James Baker
column6: and in the mid-1970s
column7: fellow punk rock pioneer Kim Salmon resided at Tarantella Night Club
column8: where he made his first public performances. John Butler of the John Butler Trio started his music career busking in Fremantle in the 1990s. Alternative rock and folk groups Little Birdy
column9: The Waifs and Eskimo Joe all have Fremantle connections
column10: and belong to what has been dubbed the 'Freo Sound'. Other notable Fremantle musicians include bassist Martyn P. Casey
column11: psychedelic rock groups Tame Impala and Pond
column12: and indie pop band San Cisco. Songs about Fremantle include the title track of Paul Kelly's 1987 album Under the Sun
column14: and much of Eskimo Joe's 2004 album A Song is a City. Fremantle is home to a number of independent labels
column16: co-run by Jebediah frontman and Fremantle-native Kevin Mitchell
column18: co-founded by the John Butler Trio and The Waifs. Music festivals held in Fremantle include the West Coast Blues & Roots Festival
column20: and the St Jerome's Laneway Festival. The Fremantle Eisteddfod
column21: running annually at the Fremantle Town Hall
column22: supports young artists with prizes and concerts.Fremantle has served as the setting for several films. Windrider (1986) was shot in Fremantle and starred Nicole Kidman. In the 2004 film Thunderstruck
column23: four devoted AC/DC fans travel across Australia from Sydney to Fremantle to bury their best friend next to Bon Scott's grave. Shooting for the 2006 film Last Train to Freo took place outside Fremantle railway station
column24: while scenes in the 2010 musical film Bran Nue Dae were shot in Fremantle's West End. Other films shot and/or set in Fremantle include Wind (1992)
column25: Teesh and Trude (2003) and Two Fists

column1: The children's television series The Sleepover Club and Streetsmartz were set and shot in Fremantle. In 2006
column2: Fremantle Prison was featured on an episode of the American version of The Amazing Race. Episodes of the BBC World documentary television series Peschardt's People have been filmed in Fremantle
column3: including an episode with Australian actress Toni Collette and another with Fremantle-based English comedian Ben Elton.

column1: Actors from Fremantle include Emma Booth
column2: Ewen Leslie
column3: David Frankflin
column4: Mary Ward and Simon Lyndon. Sam Worthington and Megan Gale attended their first acting classes at John Curtin College of the Arts in Fremantle. In 2009
column5: Fremantle model Tahnee Atkinson won the fifth cycle of Australia's Next Top Model.

column1: Global attention turned to Fremantle when it hosted the America's Cup yachting race in 1987
column2: after Australia was the first country to ever win the race
column3: aside from the US
column4: in 1983. The unsuccessful cup defence was conducted on the waters in Gage Roads
column5: and is considered a hallmark event of the late 20th century revitalisation and gentrification of the city. Fremantle has subsequently served as a stopover in the Clipper
column6: Velux and Volvo round-the-world yacht races
column7: and hosted the 2011 ISAF Sailing World Championships
column8: a major qualifying event for the 2012 Summer Olympics.

column1: Organised Australian rules football was first played in Fremantle in the early 1880s with the Fremantle Football Club
column2: a founding member of the West Australian Football Association in 1885. The club disbanded at the end of the 1886 season after winning its first premiership. Founded in 1882
column3: the Fremantle-based Unions Football Club entered WAFA in 1886
column4: attracting many players from the original Fremantle club
column5: and went on to dominate the competition with ten premiership victories. The Unions folded in 1899 and were superseded by East Fremantle (1898–)
column6: South Fremantle (1900–)
column7: and North Fremantle (1901–1915). The East Fremantle Sharks are by far the most successful club in the West Australian Football League
column8: winning a total of 29 premierships. East Fremantle Oval has been the team's home ground since 1953. Today Fremantle is represented in the Australian Football League by the Fremantle Dockers
column9: who previously trained at the heritage-listed Fremantle Oval
column11: and play their home matches at Perth Stadium (also known as Optus Stadium) in Burswood. The club's main rivalry is with the Perth-based West Coast Eagles. In 2013
column12: the Dockers played in (and lost) their first Grand Final.Founded in 1887
column13: the Fremantle District Cricket Club competes in the Western Australian Grade Cricket competition
column14: and plays its home fixtures at Fremantle's Stevens Reserve. The club has produced a number of Test players including Graeme Wood
column16: Geoff Marsh and sons Shaun Marsh and Mitchell Marsh. Three Fremantle soccer teams compete in Football West State League competitions: Fremantle Spirit
column17: Fremantle United and the Fremantle Croatia Soccer Club.

column1: Fremantle is home to five beaches: Bathers Beach
column2: River Beach
column3: South Beach
column4: Leighton Beach and Port Beach. The city's strong afternoon sea breeze
column5: known locally as the Freo Doctor
column6: has made its beaches a prime location for wind and kite surfing. The Fremantle Surf Life Saving Club has been active since the 1930s. Fishing takes place at the many jetties and groynes surrounding Challenger
column7: Success Boat and Fishing Boat harbours
column8: and along Blackwall Reach at the Swan River
column9: which is also used for canoeing
column10: rock climbing and cliff diving. A chain of islands listed as A Class nature reserves lie within 20 km (12 mi) of Fremantle
column11: and are accessible by ferry or private boat. The largest and most well-known island is Rottnest Island
column12: followed by Garden Island and Carnac Island. Each island is home to endemic flora and fauna
column13: and provide opportunities for water-based activities such as sunbathing

column1: Fremantle is home to Western Australia's largest working port. The Inner Harbour
column2: in Fremantle itself
column3: handles almost the entire container trade for the state
column4: as well as livestock exports
column5: motor vehicle imports and general cargo. Located fifteen kilometres south of Fremantle
column6: at Kwinana
column7: the Outer Harbour is one of Australia's major bulk cargo ports
column8: handling a variety of bulk commodities
column9: from grain to LPG.The city is the western terminus of the direct
column10: electrified passenger railway service from the Perth CBD. Fremantle was the starting point of railways in the metropolitan area of Perth
column11: the Fremantle railway line being the starting point of the first railway in 1881 to Guildford.

column2: the Stirling Highway
column3: Canning Highway and Leach Highway connect Fremantle to the Perth CBD.

column1: Passenger ferries operate from the port
column2: travelling to Rottnest Island
column3: 22 kilometres off of the coast in the Indian Ocean
column4: and upriver to Perth city centre. Fremantle's free Central Area Transit (CAT) bus services are popular and practical ways to get around
column5: with two services linking key points in the city and to Fremantle's inner suburbs.

column1: The major health service facility in Fremantle is Fremantle Hospital
column2: located at Alma Street
column3: a short walk from the city centre. Fremantle Hospital is a 450-bed major acute-care teaching hospital with important tertiary links. The 24-hour emergency department was closed in 2015.  It is Western Australia's referral hospital for diving and hyperbaric medicine
column4: and has a cardiothoracic surgery centre and nuclear medicine department. It also has a 66-bed mental health facility.

column2: Fremantle Hospital provides almost all specialty services on site and clinical services are backed by an extensive teaching program. As well as routine departmental and hospital-wide teaching
column3: formal postgraduate courses are offered. Emergency nursing
column4: critical care nursing
column5: perioperative nursing and infection control courses are held regularly and a postgraduate weekend for general practitioners is held every October.

column1: Fremantle has sister city relationships with five cities and friendship city relationships with three cities. Some of the relationships reflect Fremantle's historic migrant population. They are (in chronological order):

Japan (since 1979)
Italy (since 1983)
Italy (since 1984)
